factsheet.heading: GOOD FOOD MATTERS + CHOOSE LOVE
paragraphs:
Jane a former artist is now a gold medal award winning garden designer – collaborating with Good Food Matters to find a home for her beautiful garden to being long term peace and time to enjoy nature for those disposed by war, conflict, and discrimination.
Choose Love Croydon Garden for RHS Chelsea 2023 will describe in planting refugee journeys and experiences.
The show garden will be relocated after the show at Good Food Matters.

•	A Hawthorn trees
•	Boulder seating
•	A limestone paths
•	A Superadobe* wall
•	Planting familiar in the middle east and Mediterranean

The garden creates a calm, quiet sheltered place for people to sit and have informal conversations or counselling support.   it. 
 
Good Food Matters community volunteers including from the refugee community will be involved in the choice of plants, tending the pants for the garden, and creating the wall.

Superadobe is a cutting-edge sustainable technique that involves building walls with bags of earth and rendering it. 
This sense of uncertainty and flux in the lives of displaced people is conveyed through a wind activated kinetic sculpture, a dry stream bed path representing waterway migrations and a weathered tree shaped by the wind.

Key plants and shrubs -The medicinal herb Ozothamnus hookeri (Kerosene bush) from Jekka McVicar’s herb nursery makes its debut at Chelsea. Native to SE Australia and Tasmania this plant has migrated north and is now found throughout the Mediterranean basin.

A wide range of herbs that originate from the Middle East, Afghanistan, and the Mediterranean, some of which will be grown by refugee gardeners now living in the UK at Good Food Matters  .  Finally, a range of historic Iris from the famous Cayeux nursery in France are inspired by Iris species native to the Middle East.
